context: The initial prototype shown in May 2005 featured <b5_0>two<b5_0/> HDMI ports, <b7_0>three<b7_0/> Ethernet ports and <a0_0><b9_0>six<b9_0/><a0_0/> <b8_0>USB<b8_0/> ports; however, when the system was shown again a year later at E3 2006, these were reduced to one HDMI port, <a1_0><b10_0>one<b10_0/><a1_0/> Ethernet port and four USB ports, presumably <a2_0><b11_0>to cut <b6_0>costs<b11_0/><b6_0/><a2_0/>. Two hardware configurations were also announced for the console: a 20 GB model and a <a3_0><b12_0>60 GB<b12_0/><a3_0/> model, priced at US$499 (€499) and US$599 (€599), respectively. The 60 GB model was to be the only configuration to feature an HDMI port, Wi-Fi internet, flash card readers and a chrome trim with the logo in <a4_0><b13_0>silver<b13_0/><a4_0/>. Both models were announced for a simultaneous worldwide release: November 11, 2006, for Japan and November 17, 2006, for North America and Europe.
